title: Biochemistry of Health and Disease
requirements: Not for students who have taken LSCI1002.
description: This course provides a general introduction to the biochemistry of health and disease. Topics covered include nutrition and health, biomolecules and energy metabolism, molecular genetics and its applications in modern medicine, the immune system in health and disease, and the biochemistry of cancer. It is suitable for students (other than those who major in Life Sciences) who want to learn about the biochemical basis of various cellular functions and their relevance to disease. This course provides the fundamental knowledge that is essential to the study of other biochemistry or life science courses.
outcome: After completing the course, students should be able to: 1. describe the nutrients derived from diet and their functions.  2. explain the basic features, functions, and clinical relevance of enzymes.  3. discuss how energy is produced from metabolism of nutrients and the clinical significances.  4. explain how genetic information is encoded and executed in cells, and applications of recombinant technology.  5. discuss how the immune system protects us from pathogens, and the clinical manoeuvres of the immune system.  6. describe the cause and treatment strategy of cancer.  完成課程以後，學生應該掌握以下重點： 1. 膳食中的營養成份以及其功效 2. 酶的基本特性，功效和臨床上的應用 3. 能量是如何由營養成份代謝而產生及其在臨床應用上的重要性 4. 在細胞中遺傳信息如何得以編碼和解碼，以及重組技術的實際應用 5. 免疫系統是如何保衛我們遠離病原體的侵害，以及臨床上的免疫調控 6. 腫瘤的起因和治療方法  完成课程以后，学生应该掌握以下重点： 1. 膳食中的营养成份以及其功效 2. 酶的基本特性，功效和临床上的应用 3. 能量是如何由营养成份代谢而产生及其在临床应用上的重要性 4. 在细胞中遗传信息如何得以编码和译码，以及重组技术的实际应用 5. 免疫系统是如何保卫我们远离病原体的侵害，以及临床上的免疫调控 6. 肿瘤的起因和治疗方法

title: Introduction to Biological Sciences
description: This course covers basic concepts in cell biology, genetics, physiology, ecology and evolution. Students will be introduced to current advances in genetic engineering, human genome project, reproductive technology, infectious diseases, cancer biology, biodiversity conservation and human evolution.
outcome: Students will be able to describe, integrate, and apply basic concepts of biological sciences, including fundamentals of biochemistry, cell biology, genetics and physiology.  Students will possess the fundamental knowledge that facilitates their learning in higher level courses of major programmes in life sciences.  Students will develop generic skills necessary in life sciences, including acquisition of appropriate study techniques, ability to ask critical questions, and application of problem-solving skills.  Students, through what they have learnt, will be able to develop popular science educational materials for their peers and high-school students.  學生將能夠描述、整合、並應用生物科學的基本概念，包括基本生物化學、細胞生物學、遺傳學、和生理學。  學生將具備生命科學的基本知識，有利於他們學習更進階的有關的課程。  學生將發展在生命科學領域所必需的能力，包括適當的學習技巧、判性思維和解決問題的能力。  學生將能通過學到的知識，為同輩及高中學生開發科普教材。

title: Life Sciences for Engineers

description: This course gives engineering students exposure to some of the basic and essential concepts in biology and biotechnology. Topics include cell structure and energy metabolism, DNA structure and replication, protein structure and function, genetic engineering, stem cell and tissue regeneration, neural biology, cardiovascular system, muscle and skeletal system of animals, microbes and microbial biotechnology. The overall aim of this course is to introduce students with the fundamental ideas and concepts in life sciences especially those with relevance to engineering studies.

description: This course describes the chemical structures and biological functions of hormones in vertebrates with special emphasis on human subjects. title: Evolutionary Biology
requirements:
For students in MPhil-PhD Biochemistry; or Biology; or Environmental Science; or Food & Nutritional Sciences; or Molecular Biotechnology; or Cell and Molecular Biology
Not for students who have taken BIOL4010
description: This course introduces students to the pattern and processes of evolution. The course begins with an introduction of the history and philosophy of evolutionary ideas, followed by the genetics of adaptation, natural selection and speciation, and then on to the geological record and the fossil record of origination and extinction, and finishes with a discussion of the principle and practice of phylogenetic analyses and the molecular basis of evolution. Case studies on the use of molecular data in the study of evolutionary processes, biogeography and the history of life (including human evolution) will be included. This course is specially designed for advanced level of undergraduates, not only because of the course content, but it requires the students to think and integrate knowledge learnt from different courses in biology, molecular biology, cell biology, biotechnology, genetics, ecology, etc. In addition, a problem will be initiated by students and to be solved via searching for knowledge and information from diverse channels not only limited to scientific journal articles. Furthermore, a voluntary/optional field trip is organized for the students to define the problem of their own interests. These will help students to understand and analyse the problems from various aspects and multiple angles. Feedbacks will be provided throughout the course at different checkpoints.
outcome: Knowledge  • understand the key concepts in evolutionary biology  • understand and evaluate the research methods in evolutionary biology • understand the principle and practice of phylogenetic analysis and its relationships to biological classification  • understand the molecular basis of evolution and the use of molecular data in studies on evolutionary processes, biogeography, and the history of life  • understand the linkage between the modern theory of evolution and other biological disciplines such as zoology, botany, genetics, ecology and molecular biology  Skill  • understand and communicate ideas in biological evolution to individuals with or without scientific background  Value • Appreciate the importance of evolutionary analysis in areas including medicine, conservation biology and arthropology  • Familiar with important questions and key issues in evolutionary biology
syllabus: 1. History of evolutionary theory 2. Variation/Adaptation/Natural selection  3. Population genetics  4. Species concepts 5. Reproductive isolation mechanisms 6. Speciation 7. Classification and phylogeny 8. Molecular evolution and phylogenetics 9. Introduction  10. Molecular tools and data interpretation  11. History of the use of molecular data in evolutionary studies  12. Genetic variations in natural populations and gene flow  13. Species phylogeny and macroevolution  14. Fossil record 15. History of biodiversity 16. Rates of evolution 17. Extinction & mass extinction  Students are expected to revise the teaching materials after every single lecture, as the concepts keep building on each other as the course proceeds. Students are also expected to keep reading different scientific research papers throughout the course for preparation and hand-in the essay of any topics related to evolutionary biology. At the end of September, students are required to hand in the title and 3 key references of his/her own chosen topic based on interests. At the end of October, the students are required to hand in an abstract of the essay. And at the end of November, students will be handing the final essay of their own chosen topics. Students will appreciate the importance of evolutionary analysis in other disciplines such as medicine, conservation biology and arthropology; and also get familiar with important questions and key issues in evolutionary biology.

description: This course will discuss the impact of global environmental changes on biological systems and their ecosystem services. We will focus on how global warming, and associated changes such as altered rainfall, sea level rise, and ocean acidification, have changed the biological communities of the Earth’s various ecosystems, from forests to coral reefs. The impact at biological levels from molecules to cells, organisms, populations, and communities will be explored. Models for projecting future changes in Earth systems, biological communities and ecosystem services under climate change will be introduced. While the major focus is on climate change, other aspects of global environmental change, such as habitat deterioration, will also be considered. Students are required to present case studies of global change biology based on latest research findings.

title: Techniques in NGS Sequencing Library Preparation
requirements: For students in MPhil-PhD Biology; or MPhil-PhD Molecular Biotechnology; or MPhil-PhD Cell and Molecular Biology
description: This course contains lectures and laboratory practice sections related to sequencing techniques in genomics, transcriptomics, and epigenetics. This course will focus on molecular biology experiment methods (aka wet lab skills) such as genomic DNA sequencing, RNA-Seq, small RNA-Seq, chromatin immunoprecipitation sequencing (ChIP-Seq), DNaseI-Seq, ATAC-Seq and whole-genome bisulfite sequencing. In addition, a genomic technology known as optical mapping that is complementary to sequencing will also be discussed and performed.
outcome: The students will be able to perform1. DNA-Seq2. RNA-Seq and sRNA-Seq3. ChIP-Seq and DAP-Seq4. DNaseI-Seq and ATAC-Seq5. WGBS-Seq6. Optical mapping analysis
syllabus: The purpose of this course is to get an in-depth understanding in the molecular basis of current NGS techniques with a special focus on different strategies related Illumina sequencing library preparation. Advantages and disadvantages of current sequencing technologies and their implications on the sequencing result implication will be discussed. The course layout has been adapted to the needs of beginners in the field of NGS. However, molecular biology background is required.
